fields.title: heritage__file-search__help
fields.html:
File Type Filters:
Selecting one or more document type(s) from the file type drop-down list will restrict the search results by document type. If the list is empty or if all items in the list are checked, then the search will not be restricted by file type. The Clear Filters button will reset the list of selected file types to its default setting. By default, the search does not filter results by file type.
Selecting all or none of the file types in the list are functionally equivalent
Excerpts:
Where search terms are found in a document, the text surrounding that (or those) search terms is snipped out. The size of the excerpts can be determined by adjusting the number of excerpt characters.
The default excerpt size is set to 500 characters.
Search modifiers:
OR
Requires that either term (or both terms) be present for a document to match:
bear OR salmon
AND
Requires both terms on either side of the AND modifier to be present for a document to match.

This is the search default and is not required explicitly, but is good practice when building complex search statements:

salmon AND herring
NOT
Requires that the following term not be present.
bear NOT elk
(   )
Parentheses can be used to group search clauses into sub-queries:
(bear OR salmon) AND herring
(bear AND salmon) NOT elk
"   "
Phrased searches. Enclosing search terms with quotes will look for exact phrase matches:
"How to navigate in the fog with no compass"
Wildcards:
?
Matches a single character:
bo?t will match boat and bolt.
*
Multiple characters (matches zero or more sequential characters):
fi* will match fist, first, and fish.
te*t will match test and text.
*est will match rest, pest, test, and smallest.
Example of a complex query using modifiers and wildcards:
(nets OR traps) AND (sal* AND ?ear)

fields.title: heritage__interview-list__help
fields.html:
This page shows a list of all the Heritage Interviews in your database.

Instructions
Filter the table by typing in the Filter... field. Here is what the table filters on:
  • Project - enter part of the Interview title
  • Interviewer Initials - enter an interviewer initial(s)
  • Participant Number - enter a participant number
Examples
  • Try typing 'CW' - returns all the interviews led by CW
  • Try typing "07" - returns all the 2007 interviews

fields.title: development__project-create__help
fields.html:
Create a new Development Project entry using this form.

Instructions
Fill out as many or as few fields as you need to track the project. Note that you will enter Spatial Location data after initialing creating the Project.

The mandatory fields are:
  • Cedar Project name
  • Cedar project code
  • Consultation stage
Recommendations
    • Name - recommend uses a standardized format that clearly summarizes the project: APPROX-LOCATION - COMPANY - PERMIT-TYPE - DATE. Abbreviate location and company names and use a date format of YEARMONTHDAY. See example below.
    • Tags - any phrase that adds this project to a group of projects
    Examples
      • Name example: "Deep Bay - ABC Forest - LOO x2 Log Drops - 20160418"
      • Tag examples - "forestry" or "archaeology"

fields.title: development__project-list__help
fields.html:
This page lists all the Development Projects currently being tracked.

What are Development Projects?
A Development Project is any project, activity or initiative on territorial lands or waters that has the potential to have an impact. Development Projects may have negative impacts (e.g. pollution, resource use, impact on medicinal plant sites) and/or positive impacts (e.g. jobs, training, access). Development Projects usually have contacts, important dates, stages and spatial locations.

Development Project examples
  • a "Crown referral" or permit application forwarded by the BC or Canadian government
  • a permit or use approval sought by a Band Member
  • a fee simple land parcel
Table instructions
Filter the table by typing in the Filter field. Here is what the table filters on:
  • Project Name - enter part or all of the title
  • Project Code - enter part or all of a code
  • Tags - enter a tag
  • Consultation Stage - enter a stage (e.g. 'collect')
Use the SETTINGS button to change which fields are shown in the table, and to change how many rows are shown in the table.

Instructions for logging new projects
Follow these steps:
  1. Click on the ADD PROJECT button and fill out the form.
  2. Enter Spatial Location data after initialing creating the Project.

fields.title: development__project-detail__help
fields.html:
This page lists all the information for one Development Project.

Tab instructions
Click on the tabs to view additional information:
  • MAIN - People, dates and description
  • LOCATION - an interactive map and spatial upload tools (see notes below on exploring the map)
  • FILES - Any uploaded fiels describing the Project

Instructions for editing a project's general information
Follow these steps:
  1. Click on the EDIT PROJECT button and edit out the form.
  2. Click UPDATE PROJECT button.

Instructions for editing a project's spatial location
Follow these steps:
  1. Click on the the LOCATION tab.
  2. Click on the add_location button in the map.
  3. Fill out the form (see instructions on that page).
  4. Use the mode_edit and delete buttons to edit (e.g. re-upload/draw) or delete a spatial layer for this Project's location..
  5. "Drill-down" - Click on the drill-down play_for_work button and click on overlapping spatial layers to get more information.

Instructions for adding a file to a project
Follow these steps:
  1. Click on the ADD FILE button and fill out the form.
  2. Click the green FILE button to select a file from your computer.
  3. Choose what type of file from the Asset type list.
  4. Add a Comment. The is especially useful to note when, who and where the file is from.
  5. Click ADD PROJECT FILE button.

fields.title: geoinfo__spatiallayer-create__help
fields.html:
• listNew Spatial Layer Instructions

Spatial location options
There are several ways to define a spatial location:
  • File - upload a spatial file, e.g. ESRI Shapefile, Google KMZ
  • Draw on a map - draw poins, lines and/or polygons on an interactive map
  • WKT - enter "well-know text" format string. More information @ .
  • Custom - use a custom form

General steps
  1. Add a descriptive name for the location layer you are creating. If you are adding more than one spatial location, add numbers to the layer names. Here are some examples:
    • E.g. for a development project: "DP-00XX footprint 1 WKT" and "DP-00XX footprint 2 Shapefile".
    • E.g. for a general reporting layer: "Aggregate marine bird forage areas" or "Sport fishing boat reports 2016".
  2. Select a type (then follow specific steps listed below).
  3. Adding notes is optional but strongly recommended. For example, you should add where, when and from who the data/file came from.

Instructions for using Shapefile
Follow these steps:
  1. Preparation: Shapefiles must be a zipped collection of all the individual Shapefile files. It is recommended that the name of the zip file be the same as the contained files. E.g. "project_polygon.zip" would include the following files: project_polygon.shp, and project_polygon.dbf and project_polygon.prj. Multi-part polygons are NOT allowed.
  2. (Optional) Preparation: Use ArcGIS or QGIS to examine the dbf file and determine what attribute labels are available. Make note of these labels and think about the titles you would like for individual features in the map layer.
  3. (Optional) Designate an automatically generated feature label, e.g. My layer feature %ID% %poly name%. Note that feature labels are not available from KMZ files.
  4. Select File and add (a) Title and (b) Notes as instructed above above.
  5. Click the FILE button and locate the zipped Shapefile on your local system.
  6. Click CREATE PROJECT LOCATION or CREATE LAYER. The system will parse the Shapefile, creating (1st) a layer and then (2nd) ingesting all the contained features.

Instructions for using KMZ (zipped Google KML file)
Follow these steps:
  1. Preparation: Save/export your layer(s) in Google Earth as a KMZ. Warning: don't make this too complex! Also note that feature attributes are not always ingested from a KMZ.
  2. Select File and add (a) Title and (b) Notes as instructed above above.
  3. Click the FILE button and locate the GMZ file on your local system.
  4. Click CREATE PROJECT LOCATION or CREATE LAYER. The system will parse the KMZ, creating (1st) a layer and then (2nd) ingesting all the contained features.

Instructions for using Draw on a map
Follow these steps:
  1. Select Draw on a map and add (a) Title and (b) Notes as instructed above above.
  2. Zoom and pan the map to your desired location. Use the zoom buttons, and mouse-dragging.
  3. Activate the pencil button to create one or more point features. Each single-mouse-click with the pencil button activated will add a point feature.
  4. Activate the line button to create one or more line features. Start a line with a single-mouse-click and add vertices (turns) with another single-mouse-click. End the line drawing with a double-mouse-click.
  5. Multiple line features are allowed.
  6. Activate the polygon button to create one or more polygons. Start a polygon with a single-mouse-click and add vertices (turns) with another single-mouse-click. End the polygon drawing with a double-mouse-click.
  7. It is a good habit to deactivate your tool by clicking the hand tool.
  8. Edit your features by clicking on the edit button. Point: select and move. Line: select, then move a vertice or add a vertice by dragging an intermediate vertice. Polygon: select and move any vertices, and/or create a new vertices by dragging an intermediate vertices.
  9. Delete features using the Delete all features link below the map.

Instructions for WKT
Follow these steps:
  1. Select WKT and add (a) Title and (b) Notes as instructed above above.
  2. Copy and paste the WKT text into the "Wkt" field.
  3. Click CREATE PROJECT LOCATION or CREATE LAYER. The system will parse the WKT, creating (1st) a layer and then (2nd) ingesting all the contained features.

Instructions for Custom
Follow these steps:
  1. More information to be added here...

fields.title: geoinfo__map-explore-general__help
fields.html:
How to use the Slippy Map (General)

Cedar uses interactive or 'slippy' maps to show you spatial locations.

Instructions
Try these:
  • Zoom - click the +/- buttons at the top-left of the map OR use your scroll wheel OR pin gesture on a tablet or touch screen
  • Pan - drag you cursor or finger/stylus on a touch screen
  • Show in Full Screen - click to see the map expand to show in your full browser window
  • Base Map - Use the radio buttons in the Layer Legend, top-right of map, to choose a base map like Open Street Map (OSM) Mapquest or Mapquest Satellite
  • Overlay Layer(s) - turn on/off the overlay layers using the checkmark buttons below the Basemap layers. Overlay layers may have a Pencil button and a Garbage-can button: use these to edit or delete the overlay layer.

fields.title: crm__person-list__help
fields.html:
This page lists all the Persons currently in the Contacts database. Persons are shown 20 to a page.

Table instructions
Use the pagination tool to move between pages.
Click on the Contact's name to view details.
Filter the table by typing in the Filter... field search. Here is what the table filters on:
  • Contact's first and /or last name, including part of a name
  • Contact's organization
  • Contact's role / job title
  • Indigenous Names
How to reset the filters/table To reset the table, delete all terms in the Filter field and press Enter on your keyboard, or reload the page using the browser reload button refresh.

Examples
Try exploring the table by:
  • Entering a job title e.g. 'interviewer' to the Filter field - to see all interviewer contacts
  • Entering part of a term, e.g. 'da' - returns several results
  • Entering an Indigenous Name, e.g. 'Jingwas'
  • Entering an organization name (or part of such term)

fields.title: crm__organization-list__help
fields.html:
Title: crm:organization-list:help This page lists all the Organizations currently in the Contacts database. Organizations are shown 20 to a page.

Table instructions
Use the pagination tool to move between pages.
Click on the Contact's name to view details.
Filter the table by typing in the Filter... field search. Here is what the table filters on:
  • Organization's name, including part of a name
How to reset the filters/table To reset the table, delete all terms in the Filter field and press Enter on your keyboard, or reload the page using the browser reload button refresh.

Examples
Try exploring the table by:
  • Entering an organization name, or part of a name e.g. 'Hai' to the Filter field

fields.title: geoinfo__spatialreport-detail__help
fields.html:
{% load static %}
  • listSpatial Report Page Instructions

Notes
codeThe Report query script starts as soon as the page loads. Note the moving band of colour at the top of the page. This means that the query is actively comparing the Report On and the Report Against layers' features.
codeCalculating proximity hits and distances is an intensive task for the server, especially if the layers are rich with features. Be patient.
codeYou can interupt the query at any time - it will not damage the database. Interupt the query script by changing one of the layers (items) or by clicking DISMISS on the bottom-left of the page.

Explore the Report Page
Each Report page has (1) a header, (2) a layers column on the left side, and (3) a main Results section on the right.

1. Header parts
  • Report name
  • Results statistic (number of overlapping or proximal features)
  • An mode_editEDIT button - click to change the Report name.
  • A deleteDELETE button - click to delete this Report.
  • A help button.

2. Layers Column parts
  • Report name
  • Results statistic (number of overlapping or proximal features)
  • Report on layer (item) - Change the layer by clicking on the mode_edit pencil icon. You could, for example, change its distance cap.
  • Report against layers (items) - Add another layer by clicking on the blue + button; Change a layer by clicking on the mode_edit pencil icon
    • ;Remove a layer from the lsit of Report on layers by clicking on the delete garbage can icon.

3. Main Results Report parts
  • LIST tab - provides a list of all 'hits'; Report aginst features that are intersecting and/or proximal to the Report on target layer's feature(s).
  • MAP tab - shows a map of the Report on (taget layer features and any Report against layer features that meet the distance cap rule. The map usually loads faster as distance calculations do not have to be completed.

3.b. How to use the Slippy Map
Try these:
  • Map feature(s) (red)- the Report on layer features. Click for feature info (pop-up).
  • Map feature(s) (blue) - the 'hits', the results, features that are proximal or overlapping. Click for feature info (pop-up).
  • Zoom - click the +/- buttons at the top-left of the map OR use your scroll wheel OR pin gesture on a tablet or touch screen
  • Pan - drag you cursor or finger/stylus on a touch screen
  • Show in Full Screen - click to see the map expand to show in your full browser window
  • Base Map - Use the radio buttons in the Layer Legend, top-right of map, to choose a base map like Open Street Map (OSM) Mapquest or Mapquest Satellite
  • Overlay Layer(s) - turn on/off the overlay layers using the checkmark buttons below the Basemap layers.

fields.title: geoinfo__spatialreport-list__help
fields.html:
• listSpatial Reports Page Instructions

This page lists all the Spatial Reports currently in the system, 20 to a page.

Exploring the Table
Use the pagination tool to move between pages.
Click on the Report's name to view details of the report. Note: this also runs the report.
Filter the table by typing in the Filter... field search. Here is what the table filters on:
  • Report name, including part of a name
  • Default distance cap, including part of term
  • Report on item, including part of a name.
How to reset the filters To reset the table, delete all terms in the Filter field and press Enter on your keyboard, or reload the page using the browser reload button refresh.

Examples
Try exploring the table by:
  • Names: Try entering an report name, or part of a name e.g. 'Spec' to the Filter field will get all reports with 'species' or 'special' in the name.
  • Distance cap: 'pro' Try entering a value, e.g. '5'. Note that this si a text filter not a distance filter. You cannot enter '>500m', for example.
  • Report on item: try entering the filter term 'pro'; it will show all Spatial Reports with 'project' as a Report on item. This is a handing way to see all reports used to assess Development Projects.
How to add a new Spatial Report
Click the add_circle ADD SPATIAL REPORT button top-right to start creating a new Spatial Report.

fields.title: heritage__project-list__list
fields.html:
This page lists all the Heritage Projects currently in the system. Spatial Reports are shown as cards, 10 to a page.

Filter instructions
Use the pagination tool to move between pages.
Filter the table by typing in the Filter... field search. Here is what the table filters on:
  • Project name, including part of a name
How to reset the filters To reset the table, delete all terms in the Filter field and press Enter on your keyboard, or reload the page using the browser reload button refresh.

Examples
Try exploring the table by:
  • Names: Try entering an Project name, or part of a name (e.g. 'Pha') to the filter field - results will be all reports with 'phase' and 'phabulous' in the name.
How to add a new Project
Click the add_circle ADD PROJECT button top-right to start cataloging a new project.

fields.title: geoinfo__spatiallayer-list__help
fields.html:
• listSpatial Layers Page Instructions

This page shows all the GeoInfo layers in the database.
*There are app-specific GeoInfo Layer lists in the Heritage, Development and Ecosystems Apps (in prep).

About GIS Layers
Spatial features are generated in a few differently places in the Apps:
  • Created here in the GeoInfo Tools, using the ADD LAYER button.
  • Created in the Development App as a Location for a Development Project.
  • Programmatically, from other data. For example, the HMTK Species and HMTK Culture layers are custom one-time translations of the HMTK database tables (done in May 2016). Newer data added to HMTK Species and HMTK Culure tables through the Heritage App will not be in the GeoInfo layers until another translation is made.

Table exploration instructions
The Table shows layer names, number of features, authors and creation dates, and descriptions. Note how useful a good layer description is! 20 layers are shown to a page. Use the pagination to move between pages.
Filter the table by typing in the Filter... field search. Here is what the table filters on:
  • Layer name, including part of a name
  • Description, including part of a description
How to reset the filters
To reset the table, delete all terms in the Filter field and press Enter on your keyboard, or reload the page using the browser reload button refresh.

Examples
Try exploring the table by:
  • Names: Try entering an Layer name, or part of a name (e.g. 'Ha') to the filter field - results will be all reports with 'Haanas' and 'Haida' in the name.
How to add a new Layer
Click the add_circle ADD LAYER button top-right to start creating a new Layer.

fields.title: geoinfo__spatialreport-create__help
fields.html:
• listCreate Spatial Report Instructions

This forms allows you to build a new Spatial Report.

Spatial Report generation is a two part process: Here are the parts:
  1. Create a basic report instance (this form).
  2. Add Report against layers (available on the Report page after you have created it).

Here are the Report parts
  • Name - provide a descriptive name
  • Distance cap - what is the default distance cap for all the Report against layers? This can be overwritten later on a per-layer basis.
  • Report on* layer - Which layer is the focal* layer. This can be left blank.

*The Report on or focal layer defines the feature(s) on which all other layers in the Sptial Report are compared. Think of it as "What's near this [Report on]?"

Examples
  • Pseudocode - What is near [Report on layer] in these layers [Report against 1; Report against 2]... out to a maximum distance of 500m?
    • Sensitive stream report - Which sensitive streams [Report against layer, with 100s of line features] overlap or are within 200m of crown referral BC5553333 [Report on layer, generated in Development app]?

fields.title: geoinfo__spatialreport-1general-info__help
fields.html:
• info_outlineAbout Spatial Reports

    What are Spatial Reports?
    A Spatial Report is a proximity query between two or more spatial layers. Another way to think of this is:

    "Given a location HERE, WHAT is near?"

    Terminology
    labelReport On Layer(s) - The layer, or layers, that spatially bounds the query. This is the HERE in the query. We're only interested in things that are near this target. The Report On Layer(s) has a default distance cap. If Report Against Layers do not have a distance cap set, this default is used.
    labelReport Against Layer(s) - The layer or layers containing potential hits: features that are proximal to the Report On Layer features. This is the WHAT in the query.
    labelDistance cap - The distance up to which the query is run. This helps to restrict spurious queries for huge areas. If features in the layers are 5.1 km (and further) from each other, but the Distance Caps are all 5 km, then the Report will show no results.

    Use Examples
    labelWhat sensitive streams and known fish observations (Report Against Layers) are within 500m of a particular Development Project footprint (Report On Layer)
    labelDetermine what cultural and/or species records (Report Against Layers) are within or near a proposed marine plan polygon (Report On Layers)
    label“What polygons in the marine plan layer (Report Against Layer) and the sensitive streams (lines) layer (Report Against Layer) overlap or are near Project #2 (Report On Layer)? And, if they are near, how near?”

fields.title: geoinfo__spatiallayer-1general-info__help
fields.html:
• info_outlineAbout Spatial Layers

    What are Spatial Layers
    Spatial Layers are sets of spatial features (points, lines and polygons) to be used for Spatial Reports.

    Where do these Spatial Layers come from?
    Spatial Layers are generated in a few different places in the Apps:
    codeCreated here in the Spatial Tools, using the +ADD MISC. LAYER button.
    codeCreated in the Development App as a Location for a Development Project.
    codeCreated programmatically, from other data.

    Examples
    labelCreated in the All or Misc. Layers interface: look for Layers where Type = Misc.
    labelDevelopment App: Look at any Development Project with a delineated footprint in the Location tab. This is a Spatial Layer. In the All Layers table, these layers are Type = Development.
    labelCreated programmatically: For example, the HMTK Species and HMTK Culture layers are custom translations of the ingested HMTK geodatabase tables (done in May 2016). Newer data added to HMTK Species and HMTK Culture records through the Heritage App (and admin pages) will not be in the Spatial layers until another translation is made.

fields.title: heritage__interview-detail__help
fields.html:
• listInterview Details Help

Each Interview Details page has (left) an Information column, (right) an Assets List table on the right, (below) a Species Records linked table and map, and a Cultural Records linked table and map.

Information column
  • Participant - the interviewees’) Name, email and link to CRM Person entry;
  • Staff - names, roles and links;
  • Location - where the interview sessions were held;
  • Dates - dates of sessions; and
  • Statistics - gross numbers of records collected and assets appended

Assets List table
The Assets List has these columns:
  • Name - name of asset (document) with a link for downloading. Warning: these files may be large.
  • Session - which interview session the asset relates to;
  • Type - Map, Audio, etc.; and
  • Size - in MB. This should give you an indication as to whether you should download it.

How to Filter the Assets table
Enter part of a Name or Type and the table will filter as you type. For example, typing Map will filter to table to only show Maps and Georeferenced Maps.

fields.title: heritage__records-cultural-table-map__help
fields.html:
{% load static %}
  • listCultural Records Table and Map

The Cultural Records table and map show all cultural site/story records collected in the Marine TEK interviews.

Table Notes
  • The table/map may be PRE-filtered by Interview, IF this table/map is found on an Interview Details page. If this table/map is on the main Cultural Records page, you will see ALL records.
  • The table and map are LINKED. As you filter the table, the map will automatically reload.
  • Results per page - change the number of records show in the table/map using this drop-down field. The limit is 1000 records per page.
  • Filter... - filter the table (and thus the map) by entering text strings. The following MTK fields have been indexed: ID, Use Description, Species Description, Time Frame Start Description, Time Frame End Description, Harvest Method Name, Fishing Method Description, Ecological Value Description, Species Theme Name, Temporal Trend Description, and Link Code.
  • Map - Controls - Zoom, pan and expand the map using the

Map Notes
  • Zoom - click the +/- buttons at the top-left of the map OR use your scroll wheel OR pin gesture on a tablet or touch screen
  • Pan - drag you cursor or finger/stylus on a touch screen
  • Show in Full Screen - click to see the map expand to show in your full browser window
  • Base Map - Use the radio buttons in the Layer Legend, top-right of map, to choose a base map like Open Street Map (OSM) Mapquest or Mapquest Satellite
  • Overlay Layer(s) - turn on/off the overlay layers using the checkmark buttons below the Basemap layers. Overlay layers may have a Pencil button and a Garbage-can button: use these to edit or delete the overlay layer.

Examples
  • Table - try changing the number of results from 10 (default) to 500.
  • Table - try entering “Village 32” into the Filter field - two results are returned; both village sites, one with ID =132 and the other with spatial code E032.
  • Try clicking on a feature (point, line or polygon) on the map. The pop-up will show you a name and a link to the specific record.

fields.title: heritage__records-species-table-map__help
fields.html:
{% load static %}
  • listSpecies Records Table and Map

The Species Records table and map show all species site/story records collected in the Marine TEK interviews.

Table Notes
  • The table/map may be PRE-filtered by Interview, IF this table/map is found on an Interview Details page. If this table/map is on the main Species Records page, you will see ALL records.
  • The table and map are LINKED. As you filter the table, the map will automatically reload.
  • Results per page - change the number of records show in the table/map using this drop-down field. The limit is 1000 records per page.
  • Filter... - filter the table (and thus the map) by entering text strings. The following MTK fields have been indexed: ID, Use Description, Species Description, Time Frame Start Description, Time Frame End Description, Harvest Method Name, Fishing Method Description, Ecological Value Description, Species Theme Name, Temporal Trend Description', and Link Code.
  • Map - Controls - Zoom, pan and expand the map using the

Map Notes
  • Zoom - click the +/- buttons at the top-left of the map OR use your scroll wheel OR pin gesture on a tablet or touch screen
  • Pan - drag you cursor or finger/stylus on a touch screen
  • Show in Full Screen - click to see the map expand to show in your full browser window
  • Base Map - Use the radio buttons in the Layer Legend, top-right of map, to choose a base map like Open Street Map (OSM) Mapquest or Mapquest Satellite
  • Overlay Layer(s) - turn on/off the overlay layers using the checkmark buttons below the Basemap layers. Overlay layers may have a Pencil button and a Garbage-can button: use these to edit or delete the overlay layer.

Examples
  • Table - try changing the number of results from 10 (default) to 500.
  • Table - try entering “Seabird 1970” into the Filter field - six results are returned.
  • Try clicking on a feature (point, line or polygon) on the map. The pop-up will show you a name and a link to the specific record.

fields.title: heritage__project-create
fields.html:
Create a new Heritage Project entry using this form.

Notes
  • Heritage Projects are groups of cultural interviews that collect text, audio, video and mapped data. They may fit within Traditional Use & Occupancy, Traditional Ecological Knowledge, or other research frameworks.
  • At this time, other Project data must be entered in the /admin section of the App. This applies to Interviews, Sessions, Records and Assets.


Instructions
  • Name - please keep the Name short, approximately 15 characters or less. A longer name can be added to the Background. Example: ‘TUS Ph1 2007’
  • Phase code - This is optional.
  • Start date - The start date of the Project. This is used to order the Project cards in the Projects dashboard.
  • End date - The end date of the Project. This is used to order the Project cards in the Projects dashboard.
  • Location - The community(ies) where the Project was undertaken. This is optional.
  • Background - A paragraph description of the Project. This is optional.

fields.title: heritage__species-record-detail
fields.html: MORE COMING SOON

fields.title: scratch
fields.html:
• info_outlineAbout Spatial Layers

    What are Spatial Layers
    Spatial Layers are sets of spatial features (points, lines and polygons) to be used for Spatial Reports.

    Where do these Spatial Layers come from?
    Spatial Layers are generated in a few different places in the Apps:
    codeCreated here in the Spatial Tools, using the +ADD MISC. LAYER button.
    codeCreated in the Development App as a Location for a Development Project.
    codeCreated programmatically, from other data.

    Examples
    labelCreated in the All or Misc. Layers interface: look for Layers where Type = Misc.
    labelDevelopment App: Look at any Development Project with a delineated footprint in the Location tab. This is a Spatial Layer. In the All Layers table, these layers are Type = Development.
    labelCreated programmatically: For example, the HMTK Species and HMTK Culture layers are custom translations of the ingested HMTK geodatabase tables (done in May 2016). Newer data added to HMTK Species and HMTK Culture tables through the Heritage App will not be in the Spatial layers until another translation is made..

fields.title: geoinfo__spatiallayer-edit__help
fields.html:
• listEdit Spatial Layer Instructions

Instructions
You can now make changes to these fields:
  • Name - Change the name. It is recommended that you include the Project or Heritage Interview ID in the name.
  • Location - The Input Type defaults to the method originally used to create the Spatial Layer. Update the Location using the method-specific instructions below.
  • Notes - Edit Notes text

Can I change the Input type?
Yes. However changing the Input type will delete any features created using the previous/original input.

Update Location using using revised WKT
Follow these steps:
  1. Copy and paste the updated WKT text into the "Wkt" field.
  2. Edit Notes field as needed.
  3. Click the UPDATE PROJECT LOCATION button to save your changes.

Update Location using using Draw on a map
Follow these steps:
  1. Activate the pencil button to create one or more point features. Each single-mouse-click with the pencil button activated will add a point feature.
  2. Activate the line button to create one or more line features. Start a line with a single-mouse-click and add vertices (turns) with another single-mouse-click. End the line drawing with a double-mouse-click.
  3. Multiple line features are allowed.
  4. Activate the polygon button to create one or more polygons. Start a polygon with a single-mouse-click and add vertices (turns) with another single-mouse-click. End the polygon drawing with a double-mouse-click.
  5. It is a good habit to deactivate your tool by clicking the hand tool.
  6. Edit your features by clicking on the edit button. Point: select and move. Line: select, then move a vertice or add a vertice by dragging an intermediate vertice. Polygon: select and move any vertices, and/or create a new vertices by dragging an intermediate vertices.
  7. Delete features using the Delete all features link below the map.
  8. Click the UPDATE PROJECT LOCATION button to save your changes.

Update Location using a replacement Shapefile
Follow these steps:
  1. Preparation: Shapefiles must be a zipped collection of all the individual Shapefile files. It is recommended that the name of the zip file be the same as the contained files. E.g. "project_polygon.zip" would include the following files: project_polygon.shp, and project_polygon.dbf and project_polygon.prj. Multi-part polygons are NOT allowed.
  2. (Optional) Preparation: Use ArcGIS or QGIS to examine the dbf file and determine what attribute labels are available. Make note of these labels and think about the titles you would like for individual features in the map layer.
  3. (Optional) Designate an automatically generated feature label, e.g. My layer feature %ID% %poly name%. Note that feature labels are not available from KMZ files.
  4. Select File and add (a) Title and (b) Notes as instructed above above.
  5. Click the FILE button and locate the zipped Shapefile on your local system.
  6. Click the UPDATE PROJECT LOCATION button to save your changes.

Update Location using a replacement KMZ (zipped Google KML file)
Follow these steps:
  1. Preparation: Save/export your layer(s) in Google Earth as a KMZ. Warning: don't make this too complex! Also note that feature attributes are not always ingested from a KMZ.
  2. Select File and add (a) Title and (b) Notes as instructed above above.
  3. Click the FILE button and locate the GMZ file on your local system.
  4. Click the UPDATE PROJECT LOCATION button to save your changes.

Instructions for Custom
Follow these steps:
  1. More information to be added later.

fields.title: heritage__project-detail__help
fields.html:
This page lists all the information for one Heritage Project.
Each Heritage Details page has an Information panel on the left side, and then tabbed data on the right.

Information panel (left)
The panel contains background information that you can be edited by clicking the EDIT PROJECT button.
  • Project thumbnail - An image emblematic of the project
  • Project code - An optional code for the project
  • Project location(s) - Where the heritage interviews or surveys took place
  • Tags - Quick project classifications
  • Dates - The start and end date of all the interviews
  • Background - A brief summary of the project

Tabs (middle/right)
Click on the tabs to view additional information:
  • PEOPLE - People involved in the project, arranged as cards with thumbnail images
  • INTERVIEWS (default) - A table showing interviews, interviewers codes and interview numbers
  • FILES - Any uploaded files describing the Project

Instructions for editing a project's general information
Follow these steps:
  1. Click on the EDIT PROJECT button.
  2. Edit the form.
  3. Click UPDATE PROJECT button.

Instructions for adding a file to a project
Follow these steps:
  1. Click on the ADD FILE button and fill out the form.
  2. Click the green FILE button to select a file from your computer.
  3. Choose what type of file from the Asset type list.
  4. Add a Comment. The is especially useful to note when, who and where the file is from.
  5. Click ADD PROJECT FILE button.

fields.title: heritage__record-detail-species__help
fields.html:
This page lists all the information for one Heritage Species record.

The page is divided into:
  • Title bar - The record's type and name
  • Appearances - Where the record occurs in the Interview transcripts and an excerpt of that part of the interview
  • MTK Species Fields - Species-specific data collected during GIS digitizing
  • Map (right) - The record's spatial feature (point, line or polygon) shown on an interactive map
  • MTK Record Fields - General records data collected during GIS digitizing


Map Notes
  • Zoom - click the +/- buttons at the top-left of the map OR use your scroll wheel OR pin gesture on a tablet or touch screen
  • Pan - drag you cursor or finger/stylus on a touch screen
  • Show in Full Screen - click to see the map expand to show in your full browser window
  • Base Map - Use the radio buttons in the Layer Legend, top-right of map, to choose a base map like Open Street Map (OSM) Mapquest or Mapquest Satellite
  • Overlay Layer(s) - turn on/off the overlay layers using the check mark buttons below the Basemap layers. Overlay layers may have a Pencil button and a Garbage-can button: use these to edit or delete the overlay layer.

fields.title: heritage__record-detail-cultural__help
fields.html:
This page lists all the information for one Heritage Cultural record.

The page is divided into:
  • Title bar - The record's type and name
  • Appearances - Where the record occurs in the Interview transcripts and an excerpt of that part of the interview
  • MTK Cultural Fields - Cultural-specific data collected during GIS digitizing
  • Map (right) - The record's spatial feature (point, line or polygon) shown on an interactive map
  • MTK Record Fields - General records data collected during GIS digitizing


Map Notes
  • Zoom - click the +/- buttons at the top-left of the map OR use your scroll wheel OR pin gesture on a tablet or touch screen
  • Pan - drag you cursor or finger/stylus on a touch screen
  • Show in Full Screen - click to see the map expand to show in your full browser window
  • Base Map - Use the radio buttons in the Layer Legend, top-right of map, to choose a base map like Open Street Map (OSM) Mapquest or Mapquest Satellite

fields.title: development__project-update__help
fields.html:
Edit a Development Project using this form.

Instructions
Update as many or as few fields as you need to track the project. Note that you will add or edit Spatial Location data in the LOCATION tab.

The mandatory fields are:
  • Cedar Project name
  • Cedar project code
  • Consultation stage
Recommendations
    • Name - recommend uses a standardized format that clearly summarizes the project: APPROX-LOCATION - COMPANY - PERMIT-TYPE - DATE. Abbreviate location and company names and use a date format of YEARMONTHDAY. See example below.
    • Tags - any phrase that adds this project to a group of projects
    Examples
      • Name example: "Deep Bay - ABC Forest - LOO x2 Log Drops - 20160418"
      • Tag examples - "forestry" or "archaeology"

fields.title: heritage__search_page__help
fields.html:
{% load static %} This page is the general search page for all content in the Heritage App.

How to search
Type your search string (words or phrase) into the Search field and click ENTER or the button.

What can you search?
Cedar automatically updates its search index of the following:
  • work Projects - title and fields
  • grain Collections - title and fields
  • format_list_bulleted Items - title and fields
  • folder Case Brief - title and fields
  • device_hub Synthesis - title and fields
  • flag Place - title and fields
  • layers Layer - title and fields
  • insert_drive_file Attached Files - full text, e.g. linked to a Project (manually uploaded or harvested by MailHarvest)
  • insert_drive_file Attached Files - full text, e.g. linked to an Item (manually uploaded)

What are Excerpts?
Search will show you an excerpt of the text(s) around the found search terms. Use the Show/Hide Excerpt(#) link in the Results to view the excerpt(s) for that result. You can adjust the number of characters around the search term by changing the value in 'Number of Execerpt characters' field.

Researchers may want to download the results of their search query, including Excerpts. The results are downloaded in a comma separated values (CSV) file format that can be opened and analysed in a spreadsheet program. Download results by clicking on

Advanced: Search Query Modifiers
a. Boolean modifiers

AND - AND requires both terms on either side of the AND modifier to be present for a document to match. This is the search default and is not required explicitly, but is good practice when building complex search statements: salmon AND herring
OR - OR requires that either term (or both terms) be present for a document to match: bear OR salmon
OR - NOT Requires that the following term not be present. bear NOT elk
( ) - Parentheses can be used to group search clauses into sub-queries: (bear OR salmon) AND herring ...versus ... (bear AND salmon) NOT elk
" " - Phrased searches. Enclosing search terms with quotes will look for exact phrase matches: "How to navigate in the fog with no compass"

b. Wildcard modifiers

? - ? matches a single character: bo?t will match boat and bolt.
* - * Multiple characters (matches zero or more sequential characters): fi* will match fist, first, and fish. te*t will match test and text. *est will match rest, pest, test, and smallest.

c. Combining modifiers

Example of a complex query using modifiers and wildcards: (nets OR traps) AND (sal* AND ?ear)

d. Using field names in Search
You can do very specific searches by directing search to look for value in particular fields.
Try these examples:
  • To search for Items from a particular author enter the following into the Search Field: creator:"Brown, Pat Jr. - Interviewee" or creator:Brown* (to use a wildcard too).
  • To search for Items for a spreadsheet id enter the following into the Search Field: spreadsheet_id:"220"

Here is a list of all the current Heritage App content type field names:
Item Base Fields
name
tags
collections
cataloger
reviewer

Item Dublin Core Fields

Item Researcher Notes Fields

Case Brief Fields

Synthesis Concept Fields

fields.title: heritage__items-list__list
fields.html:
{% load static %} A page listing all the Heritage Items currently in the database that you can filter and sort. The page has the following parts: Quick Filter, (right-side) Reset, Sort, Advanced Filters and Add New. You can also use the full Heritage Search page to find content, including excerpts of text near search results.

searchQuick Filter



Use the Quick Filter to quickly find a subset of Items. Quick Filter filters on:
  • ID, with or without the prefix - e.g. try typing "I-1" or "1"
  • Name, including part of a name - e.g. try typing "I" or "Island"
  • Cataloger
  • Reviewer
  • Type
  • Creation Date
restoreReset


To reset the table, click the RESET FILTERS button, or delete all terms in the Quick Filter field and press [Enter] on your keyboard.

sortSort

Change the number of result rows by changing the Result per page value. The default is 25 results/rowsper page.

Sort the table by chosing a sort field (e.g. ID, Name) and then choose ascending or descending. The default table sort is by ID, descending.

filter_listAdvanced Filters (right side of table)
Try filtering the table by selecting values for:
  • Creation Date - after
  • Creation Date - before
  • Item Types
  • Collections
  • People Mentioned
  • Plants
  • Animals/li>
  • Spreadsheet ID/li>
Add New
Click the add_circle ADD ITEM button top-right to start cataloging a new Item.

filter_listAdvanced Filters (right side of table)

Add New
Click the add_circle CASE BRIEF button top-right to creating a new Case Brief.

fields.title: heritage__places-list__list
fields.html:

The page has the following parts: Quick Filter, (right-side) Reset, Sort, Advanced Filters and Add New. NOTE! The LIST and MAP tabs are linked. If the LIST shows only 25 Places, then the MAP will only show 25 Places. To see all Places on the MAP tab, select All from the 'Results per page', as explained below.

  • Story Title, including part of a name - e.g. try typing "I" or "Island"

filter_listAdvanced Filters (right side of table)
